Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bone as an interpenetrating composite material
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract: This collaborative project award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Illinois Urbana-Champion and University of California San Diego is to investigate a new model of bone as a material that the two phases in bone, proteins and minerals, are interpenetrating (continuous), and to explore what implications this hypothesis has on bone's mechanical properties, including strength and resistance to fracture. Bone is made of collagen and other proteins, nano-sized minerals and water, all hierarchically self-assembled. Bone has excellent properties due to its complex hierarchical structure; it is strong, stiff, tough and light weight. However, factors contributing to these superior properties are still not well understood. This fundamental and interdisciplinary study will include state-of-the art experiments and multiscale modeling, and will focus on porcine developing bone (0-48 months) which exhibits significant changes in its structure and composition with age. Results from this research will lead to better predictions of bone quality in humans, which is still an outstanding clinical issue, and will guide in the design of novel synthetic composite materials with superior mechanical properties for applications in biomedical, transportation and energy fields. Students from diverse backgrounds will participate in this cutting-edge research. New courses will be developed and short courses and other presentations will be given to technical and lay audiences.


Technical Abstract: Bone is a biological nanocomposite material made of collagen and other proteins, hydroxyapatite minerals and water, all hierarchically assembled. This complex structure gives bone its superior properties (strong, stiff, tough and light weight). However, the contributing factors are still not well understood. In this collaborative project, researchers will test two hypotheses: 1) bone is a composite material made of interpenetrating organic and mineral phases; and 2) synthetic bioinspired composites with interpenetrating phases will have superior mechanical properties, compared to composites with a dispersed reinforcing phase. More specifically, these investigators will determine if the interpenetrating model is valid for bone with varying degrees of mineralization and different microstructures via multiscale experiments and modeling. Developing porcine bone (0-48 months old), which exhibits a range of microstructures and mineral contents will be studied as part of this project. Strains at the collagen/mineral level as a function of applied stress, using high energy x-rays diffracting at small- and wide-angles, will be compared with those obtained theoretically. In addition, synthetic bioinspired materials with interpenetrating phases will be designed and tested, and compared their properties to those of composites with a dispersed reinforcement. This project is expected to provide fundamental understanding of bone's hierarchical structure, which will lead to better predictions of bone quality and will guide the design of new bioinspired synthetic composites for different applications. Students from diverse backgrounds are expected to participate in this cutting-edge research, including the students from Title V Hispanic-serving high schools. New courses will be developed, and presentations will be given to technical and lay audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a collaborative project between Prof. Iwona Jasiuk at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) and Prof. Joanna McKittrick from the University of California in San Diego (UCSD) which has focused on bone and bone-inspired materials. Bone is a biological nanocomposite material made of biopolymers (collagen and other proteins), nano-sized minerals (hydroxyapatite) and water, all hierarchically self-assembled. This project was motivated by the fact that bone has excellent mechanical properties (is strong, stiff, tough and light weight), which attribute to its complex composite and multiscale structure. However, factors contributing to these superior properties are still not well understood. Secondly, bone can serve as inspiration to design new bioinspired materials with superior properties.

The goals of this project were:

  1. Determine if the interpenetrating composite model hypothesis is valid for bone with varying degrees of mineralization and different microstructures. We used a recently developed multiscale computational model and deproteinization (remove all collagen and other organics) and demineralization (remove all hydroxyapatite minerals) experiments on bone samples;
  2. Design and test synthetic bioinspired materials fabricated by 3D printing based on the interpenetrating composite model and compare to composites with dispersed reinforcements.

Intellectual Merit:

The study of natural biological materials has emerged as an increasingly important area of research. Determining if bone is an interpenetrating composite or a composite with minerals embedded in a protein matrix (as assumed by most researchers) and the detailed knowledge of the mineral/protein interactions in bone are of essential importance for understanding nature?s optimized design. Developing new bioinspired materials is at the forefront of materials research. The proposed study utilized state-of the art experiments and modern multiscale micromechanics modeling to study bone and bioinspired materials.

The outcomes and findings are as follows: 

  • Pig bones (simulating human) were either demineralized or deproteinized to investigate the phases separately. We identified the chemical agents that performed the best and extensively examined the remaining scaffolds with microscopy and spectrographic methods.
  • We used 3D printing to form prototypes with two different polymers (stiff and soft) in different configurations. Fabrication of no-matrix, a single-matrix, and an interpenetrating-matrix model were then analyzed under compression and the results were compared to finite element results. The mechanical tests corroborated the finite element results. Contrary to the expected trends in most materials where smaller sample sizes result in higher strength, smaller 3D printed composites were shown to decrease in both strength and elastic modulus.
  • We invented a new method for the formation of bioinspired bone based on the structure of porcupine fish spines ? radial concentric freeze casting. Freeze casting is a method to produce porous, aligned ceramic scaffolds that were subsequently infiltrated with polymers. This technique was adapted to change the freezing front direction to form highly fracture resistant composite materials. For the first time, freeze casting was also used to fabricate a collagen/hydroxyapatite scaffold, using collagen extracted from the demineralization experiments. The addition of collagen cross-linkers significantly improved the strength.

Broader Impacts:

A fundamental understanding of bone?s hierarchical structure will lead to better predictions of bone quality, which is still an outstanding issue in orthopedics, and will guide the design of novel synthetic composite materials for exceptional mechanical properties. The interdisciplinary research spanned the fields of biomechanics, computational mechanics and materials science, and involved modern experiments and modeling. Students (graduate and undergraduate) from diverse backgrounds participated in this research. Three graduate students (all women) conducted this research. Diversity efforts also focused on including students from Title V Hispanic-serving institutions and high schools.

The participants routinely presented their research at national and international conferences, including several keynote and invited talks. The students delivered 46 presentations and authored 17 journal publications. Prof. McKittrick continued to teach a freshman seminar class ?Biological and Biomimetic Materials,? Winter 2016-2017. She also continues to teach a graduate class, ?Biomaterials and Medical Devices,? where results of this project are presented. Prof. Jasiuk has been incorporating findings of this research in a junior-level undergraduate Materials Behavior course. Four UCSD undergraduates and one UIUC undergraduate participated in the research. Six Latina high school students and two REU students participated during the summers 2016-2018. Both PIs organized a symposium on Mechanics of Mineralized Biological and Bioinspired Materials at the US National Congress for Theoretical and Applied Mechanics which was held in Chicago in June 2018. Also, co-PI McKittrick organized two symposia at two different international meetings. Numerous lab tours were given and demonstrations were given at visits to elementary and middle schools. 19 collaborators from around the globe advised and/or helped with the project.
